review.title: Leveraging Cognitive Features for Sentiment Analysis
review.abstract: Sentiments expressed in user-generated short text and sentences are nuanced by subtleties at lexical, syntactic, semantic and pragmatic levels. To address this, we propose to augment traditional features used for sentiment analysis and sarcasm detection, with cognitive features derived from the eye-movement patterns of readers. Statistical classification using our enhanced feature set improves the performance (F-score) of polarity detection by a maximum of 3.7% and 9.3% on two datasets, over the systems that use only traditional features. We perform feature significance analysis, and experiment on a held-out dataset, showing that cognitive features indeed empower sentiment analyzers to handle complex constructs.
histories: The SIGNLL Conference on Computational Natural Language Learning (CoNLL 2016)
review.COMMENTS: The SIGNLL Conference on Computational Natural Language Learning (CoNLL 2016)

metadata.title: Leveraging Cognitive Features for Sentiment Analysis

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: This paper deals with the task of Sentiment Analysis (SA) - the automatic recognition of sentiment polarity as positive versus negative - of user-generated short texts and sentences. Today, there are several Sentiment Analyzers in the literature (Liu and Zhang, 2012). Recent papers such as Kouloumpis et al. (2011), Agarwal et al. (2011) and Barbosa and Feng (2010) attempt to perform such analyses on user-generated content. Sentiment Analysis remains a hard problem, as summarized below, due to the challenges it presents at various levels.

sections.heading: 1.1 Lexical Challenges
sections.text: Mood analysts face three challenges on the lexical level: (1) data economy, i.e. the handling of invisible words / phrases. (2) Lexical ambiguity, i.e. the search for appropriate senses of a word in light of context (e.g. his face fell when he fell from the team against the boy from the bicycle, where the verb "fell" must be unique.) (3) Domain dependency, which deals with words that change polarity between domains. (e.g. the word unpredictably positive in case of an unpredictable film in the film sector and negative in case of unpredictable steering in the automotive sector.) Several methods have been proposed to address the different lexical difficulties by - (a) using WordNet synsets and word cluster information when lexical ambiguity and data economy (Akkaya al, Popain, 2009; Balali et al, 2011; al, 2011; al, al; Saamal, 2012).

sections.heading: 1.2 Syntactic Challenges
sections.text: Difficulties at the syntax level arise when the given text follows a complex phrase structure and phrase appendages are likely to be dissolved before SA is executed. For example, the sentence requires a somewhat roughly constructed but riveting, questioning look at a person who is so plagued by self-loathing that he becomes the enemy of his own race. It must be processed at the syntactical level before analyzing the mood. Approaches to using syntactic properties of text include generating dependency-based rules for SA (Poria et al., 2014) and using local dependency (Li et al., 2010).

sections.heading: 1.3 Semantic and Pragmatic Challenges
sections.text: This corresponds to the difficulties encountered in the higher layers of the NLP, i.e. semantic and pragmatic layers. Challenges in these layers include: (a) implicit feeling (e.g. Guy becomes girl, Guy loses girl, audience falls asleep.) (b) presence of sarcasm and different Xiv: 170 1,05 581v 1 [cs.C L] January 19, 2017Forms of irony (e.g.: This is the kind of movie you go to because the theater has an air conditioner.) and (c) thwarted expectations (e.g. the acting is fine. Action sequences are top notch. Nevertheless, I consider it to be a below-average film due to its bad storyline.) Such challenges are extremely difficult to overcome with traditional NLP tools, as they require both linguistic and pragmatic knowledge.

sections.heading: 1.4 Introducing Cognitive Features
sections.text: Our hypothesis is that cognitive processes in the brain are related to eye movement activities (Parasuraman and Rizzo, 2006). Therefore, taking into account eye movement patterns when reading sentimental texts can help to better address linguistic nuances. We perform a statistical classification based on different classification traits and different combinations of traits. With our extended trait set, we observe a significant improvement in the accuracy of all classifiers for two different datasets. Experiments on a carefully curated dataset suggest a significant improvement in psychopolarity.

sections.heading: 2 Related Work
sections.text: Sentiment classification has long been standing NLP problem with both supervised (Pang et al., 2002; Benamara et al., 2007; Martineau and Finin, 2009) and unsupervised (Mei et al., 2007; Lin and He, 2009) machine learning based techniques exist for the task.Supervised approaches are popular because of their superior classification accuracy (Mullen and Collier, 2004; Pang and Lee, 2008) and in such approach, feature engineering plays an important role. Apart from the frequently used bagof-words features based on unigrams, bigrams etc. (Dave et al., 2003; Ng et al., 2006), syntactical properties (Martineau and Finin, 2009; Nakagawa et al., 2010), semantic properties (Balamurali et al., 2011) and effect of negators.

sections.heading: 3 Eye-tracking and Sentiment Analysis Datasets
sections.text: We use two publicly available datasets for our experiments. Dataset 1 was published by Mishra et al. (2016), which they use to predict the complexity of sentiment annotations. Dataset 2 was used by Joshi et al. (2014) to predict the complexity of sentiment annotations. These datasets contain many examples with higher-level nuances such as the presence of implicit feelings, sarcasm, and thwarting. We describe the datasets below.

sections.heading: 3.1 Dataset 1
sections.text: It contains 994 snippets of text with 383 positive and 611 negative examples, 350 of which are sarcastic or have other forms of irony. The snippets are a collection of reviews, normalized tweets and quotations. Each snippet is commented on by seven participants with binary positive-negative polarity markers. Their eye movement patterns are recorded using a high-quality SR-Research Eyelink-1000 Eyetracker (sampling rate 500 Hz). Annotation accuracy varies from 70% to 90% with a Fleiss-Kappa-Interrater match of 0.62.

sections.heading: 3.2 Dataset 2
sections.text: This dataset consists of 1059 snippets, consisting of film reviews and normalized tweets. Each snippet is commented on by five participants with positive, negative and objective labeling. The eye tracking is done using a low-quality Tobii T120 Eyetracker (sampling rate 120 Hz). The accuracy of the annotations varies between 75% - 85% with a Fleiss-Kappa match of 0.68. We exclude the objective and consider 843 snippets, of which 443 are positive and 400 negative.

sections.heading: 3.3 Performance of Existing SA Systems Considering Dataset -1 and 2 as Test Data
sections.text: We use two statistical classifiers and a rules-based classifier to test the accuracy of Dataset 1 and Dataset 2. These statistical classifiers are based on Support Vector Machine (SVM) and Na ¿ive Bayes (NB) APIs implemented using Weka (Hall et al., 2009) and LibSVM (Chang and Lin, 2011) APIs. These are based on 10662 snippets consisting of film reviews and tweets randomly compiled from standard Pang and Lee (2004) and Sentiment 140 (http: / / www.sentiment140.com /) datasets. The feature set includes traditional SA characteristics reported in a series of essays. They are discussed in Section 4 under the Sentiment Features category. The in-house rule-based (RB) classifier decides the mood labels.

sections.heading: 4 Enhanced feature set for SA
sections.text: Our feature set is divided into four categories: (1) Sentiment features (2) Sarcasm, irony and thwarting of related features (3) Cognitive features related to eye movement (4) Textual features related to reading difficulties. We describe our feature set below.

sections.heading: 4.1 Sentiment Features
sections.text: We look at a number of textual characteristics that have been extensively used in sentiment literature (Liu and Zhang, 2012), which are described below. Each characteristic is represented by a unique abbreviated form that is used in subsequent debates. 1. To avoid overmatching (since our training data size is smaller), we reduce the dimension to 500 using Principal Component Analysis.2. Subjective words (Positive Words, Negative Words), i.e. the presence of positive and negative words calculated against MPQA lexicon (Wilson et al., 2005), a popular lexicon used for sentiment analysis.3. Subjective values (PosScore, Negative Words), i.e. negative words calculated against MPQA lexicon (Wilson et al., 2005), a popular lexicon used for sentiment analysis.6. Subjective values (PosScore, Negative Words), i.e. negative Score's positive subjectivity, positive subjectivity, and positive subjectivity (Net and negative).

sections.heading: 4.2 Sarcasm, Irony and Thwarting related Features
sections.text: To deal with complex texts containing, as explained above, irony, sarcasm and thwarted expectations, we consider the following characteristics: Characteristics derived from Riloff et al. (2013), Ramteke et al. (2013) and Joshi et al. (2015) 1. Implicit incongruence (IMPLICIT PCA), i.e. the presence of positive phrases followed by negative situational phrases (calculated using the bootstrapping technique proposed by Riloff et al. (2013). We consider the 500 most important components of these phrases to be dimension reducing in order to avoid overfitting.2. Punctuation marks (PUNC), i.e. the number of punctuation marks in the text. 3. Largest pos / neg sub-sequence (LAR), i.e. the length of the largest set of words with unaltered polarities. Word polarity is determined using MPQA lexicon (LP), i.e. the Sentence-polarity found by Jossus-Hi using the Regulator.

sections.heading: 4.3 Cognitive features from eye-movement
sections.text: Eye movement patterns are characterized by two basic attributes: (1) fixations that correspond to a prolonged presence of the gaze on a visual object (such as signs, words, etc.) in the text; (2) saccades that correspond to the transition of the eyes between two fixations; and, in addition, a saccades is called a regressive saccade or simply regression if it represents a phenomenon of returning to a previously visited segment; a portion of a text is skipped if it has no fixation; and Figure 1 shows the behavior of eye movements during the commentary of the given sentence in dataset-1. The circles represent 1http: / / www.nltk.org / Fixation and the line that connects the circles represent saccades. Our cognition-driven features derive from these basic attributes of eye movement. We divide our features into two groups, as explained below.

sections.heading: 4.4 Basic gaze features
sections.text: This year it has come to the point where it will be able to retaliate, "he said in an interview with the Deutsche Presse-Agentur." We have no idea yet how it will come to this result, "he said." But we have no idea yet how it will be, "he told the Deutsche Presse-Agentur." We have no idea yet how it will come to this result, "he said.

sections.heading: I will always cherish the
sections.text: can help distinguish sentences with different linguistic subtleties.

sections.heading: 4.5 Complex gaze features
sections.text: D "ir" i "s," said the chairman, "i sasds rfü ide rfü ide rfü ü ü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die for the rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die for the rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die rfü die for the rfü die rfü die rfü die

sections.heading: 4.6 Features Related to Reading Difficulty
sections.text: Eye movements when reading texts with emotional nuances (such as sarcasm) can be similar to those of texts with other difficulties. To account for the effects of sentence length, word length and number of syllables that influence reading behaviour, we consider the following characteristics: 1. Reading Facilitation (RED) i.e. Flesch Readability Ease Score of the text (Kincaid et al., 1975). The higher the score, the easier the text is to understand.2. Sentence Length (LEN) i.e. number of words in the sentence. We will now explain our experimental setup and the results.

sections.heading: 5 Experiments and results
sections.text: We test the effectiveness of the enhanced feature set by implementing three classifiers, 1.5, SVM (with linear kernel), NB and multi-layer neural network, which are implemented using the Weka (Hall et al., 2009) and LibSVM (Chang and Lin, 2011) APIs. Multiple hyperparameters of the classifier are applied to the default values specified in Weka. We perform separately a 10-fold cross-validation of both Dataset 1 and LibSVM (Chang and Lin, 2011) APIs. Average F scores for the class frequency-based random classifier are 33% and 46.93% for Dataset 1 and Dataset 2 with respect to Dataset 2. Classification accuracy is shown in Table 2. We observe maximum accuracy with the full feature set consisting of sentiment, sarcasm and thwarting, cognitive features, and cognitive features.

sections.heading: 5.1 Importance of cognitive features
sections.text: We perform a chi-square test-based significance analysis, as shown in Table 3. For data set 1, 10 of the 20 most ranked characteristics are view-based characteristics, and for data set 2, 7 of the 20 most important characteristics are view-based, as shown in bold letters. Moreover, if we consider the eye characteristics solely for the ranking of the characteristics by means of chi-square test, features FC, SL, FSDH, FSDS, RSDH, and RSDS prove to be insignificant. To investigate whether the cognitive characteristics actually contribute to classifying complex output earlier than hypotesized, we repeat the experiment on a heldout data set randomly derived from data set 1. It contains 294 text snippets, 131 of which contain complex constructs such as irony / sarcasm and the rest of the snippets are relatively simple. We choose SVM, our most powerful classifier, with a configuration similar to Table 4.

sections.heading: 6 Feasibility of our approach
sections.text: Since our method requires the availability of visual data from human readers, the practicability of the methods is questionable.

sections.heading: 6.1 Availability of Mobile Eye-trackers
sections.text: The availability of low-cost, embedded Eyetrackers on portable devices is now very close to reality, opening up opportunities to get eye-tracking data from low-cost mobile devices to a large number of online readers without intrusive intervention, and deriving cognitive traits that can be used in predictive frameworks like ours. For example, Cogisen: (http: / / www.sencogi.com) has a patent (ID: EP2833308-A1) on "Eyetracking using low-cost mobile webcams." Wood and Bulling (2014) introduced EyeTab, a model-based binocular vision approach that runs entirely on tablets.

sections.heading: 6.2 Applicability Scenario
sections.text: We believe that mobile eye tracking modules could be part of mobile applications designed for e-commerce, online learning, games, etc., where the automatic analysis of online reviews requires better solutions to detect and manage linguistic nuances in mood analysis. Suppose a book gets different reviews on Amazon. Our system could use mobile eye trackers to observe how readers read the review, thus determining the polarity of opinion, especially when the mood is not expressed explicitly (e.g. through the use of strong polar words) in the text. Such an application can be scaled horizontally across the web, helping to improve the automatic classification of online reviews.

sections.heading: 6.3 Getting Users’ Consent for Eye-tracking
sections.text: Eye tracking technology has already been used by leading mobile technology developers (such as Samsung) to provide a more comprehensive user experience through services such as smart scroll (where a user's eye movement determines whether a page needs to be scrolled or not) and smart lock (where the user's gaze position determines whether the screen is locked or not).The growing interest of users in using such services leads us to a promising situation where it will not be difficult to obtain user consent to record eye movement patterns, although this is not yet the state of the art.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion
sections.text: We combined traditional sentiment traits with (a) different textual traits used for sarcasm and thwarting recognition, and (b) cognitive traits derived from the behavior of readers "eye movements; the combined trait set improves overall accuracy over the traditional trait set, which is based on SA, by a margin of 3.6% and 9.3% for data sets 1 and 2, respectively; it is significantly effective for texts with complex constructs, resulting in a 6.1% improvement in our retained data; in the future, we propose to develop (a) deeper vision-based traits and (b) multiple classification using independent learning from linguistic and cognitive data; and we plan to explore deeper graphical and visual characteristics, as well as models for depicting complex glances; and our general approach may prove useful for other problems such as emotion analysis, text summarization, and questioning, which alone do not provide textual clues.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: We thank the members of the CFILT Lab, especially Jaya Jha and Meghna Singh, and the students of IIT Bombay for their help and support.

referenceMentions.context: Several sentiment analyzers exist in literature today (Liu and Zhang, 2012).
Recent works, such as Kouloumpis et al. (2011), Agarwal et al.
(2011), Agarwal et al. (2011) and Barbosa and Feng (2010), attempt to conduct such analyses on user-generated content.
(2011), Agarwal et al. (2011) and Barbosa and Feng (2010), attempt to conduct such analyses on user-generated content.

Several methods have been proposed to address the different lexical level difficulties by - (a) using WordNet synsets and word cluster information to tackle lexical ambiguity and data sparsity (Akkaya et al., 2009; Balamurali et al., 2011; Go et al., 2009; Maas et al., 2011; Popat et al., 2013; Saif et al., 2012) and (b) mining domain dependent words (Sharma and Bhattacharyya, 2013; Wiebe and Mihalcea, 2006).

Several methods have been proposed to address the different lexical level difficulties by - (a) using WordNet synsets and word cluster information to tackle lexical ambiguity and data sparsity (Akkaya et al., 2009; Balamurali et al., 2011; Go et al., 2009; Maas et al., 2011; Popat et al., 2013; Saif et al., 2012) and (b) mining domain dependent words (Sharma and Bhattacharyya, 2013; Wiebe and Mihalcea, 2006).

The fact that sentiment expression may be complex to be handled by traditional features is evident from a study of comparative sentences by Ganapathibhotla and Liu (2008). This, however has not been addressed by feature based approaches.
Joshi et al. (2014) develop a method to measure the sentiment annotation complexity using cognitive evidence from eye-tracking.

Joshi et al. (2014) develop a method to measure the sentiment annotation complexity using cognitive evidence from eye-tracking. Mishra et al. (2014) study sentiment detection, and subjectivity extraction through anticipation and homing, with the use of eye tracking.
Earlier, Mishra et al. (2013) measure translation annotation difficulty of a given sentence based on gaze input of translators used to label training data.

metadata.abstractText: Sentiments expressed in user-generated short text and sentences are nuanced by subtleties at lexical, syntactic, semantic and pragmatic levels. To address this, we propose to augment traditional features used for sentiment analysis and sarcasm detection, with cognitive features derived from the eye-movement patterns of readers. Statistical classification using our enhanced feature set improves the performance (F-score) of polarity detection by a maximum of 3.7% and 9.3% on two datasets, over the systems that use only traditional features. We perform feature significance analysis, and experiment on a held-out dataset, showing that cognitive features indeed empower sentiment analyzers to handle complex constructs.
metadata.creator: TeX
